geninfo.para: Chassis lean may result from manufacturing tolerances; i.e., the frame ladder assembly, leaf spring assemblies, etc. After completing the measurement steps described in the below "Service Procedure", a limited amount of shimming may be acceptable.

caution.para: Shimming is not an acceptable practice for chassis lean created by the addition of auxiliary equipment or loading practices resulting in vehicle lean. These procedures are intended to assist the service technician in making industry acceptable corrections for nominal lean issues and are not intended to compensate for over/uneven loading or un-repaired vehicle damage - regardless of cause.

Shimming is not an acceptable practice for chassis lean on air spring suspension axles. Air spring suspensions incorporate one or two (optional) height control valves and will automatically self level within design limits of the suspension system.

step1.para: Record vehicle weight at all four corners of the chassis as measured at individual wheel positions (tandems on one side in the case of 6 x 4 or 6 x 6) to verify the vehicle is not overloaded or unevenly loaded. Steel spring suspensions will deflect, based upon applied spring loads. Air springs incorporate a height control valve and will automatically self-level within the design limits of the suspension package.
Assure that all tires are properly inflated to recommended pressures, based upon the heaviest loads normally carried and park the chassis on a known level surface.

Measure the distance from the bottom of the frame rail to the level ground surface on both sides at the steer axle and at the rear suspension. If the difference side to side exceeds 3/8 inch (9.5 mm), shimming is an acceptable corrective practice. Exchanging the front springs (right for left and left for right) is also an acceptable corrective practice.

caution.para: Maximum shim thickness for steer axles shall be no more than 3/8 inch (9.6 mm). Steering and handling performance may be adversely affected if maximum shim thickness for steer axles of 3/8 inch (9.6 mm) is exceeded.

Maximum shim thickness for drive axles shall be no more than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm). Handling and driveline performance may be adversely affected if shim thickness for drive axles of 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) is exceeded.

item.para: When shimming a suspension pack, make sure U-bolts are of sufficient length that when final assembly is accomplished a minimum of 2 threads are showing on the U-bolt legs beyond the nuts. If U-bolts have to be replaced, use only International recommended material.

When shimming a suspension pack, make sure spring locating lug or center bolt head is of sufficient length to properly engage through the shim and into the axle seat to assure proper spring alignment.

Should new front springs be installed as a corrective action, visually compare the springs for even height. If one spring is slightly higher than the other, install the higher (taller) spring on the lower side as stated in Step 3 above.

caution.para: Re-torque U-bolts per International Owner's Manual / Service Procedure, and at recommended intervals for a new vehicle after completion.
